I doubt that Easyrider is simply claiming, without any qualification by reference to the gospels, that the moral laws of the Old Testament are in force right now. I suspect he has a more complicated theory of Christian ethics which his adversaries wish to distort in order to score cheap points in a tone of relentless hostility. (That's my impression in this and other threads). 
 
 The sacred texts of Judaism are the foundation of Christianity, but the mission of Jesus Christ represents a new era in God's dealing with humanity - so much of the extensive body of Jewish law was/is no longer relevant. The Old Testament was revealed only to Israel; the New Testament is a revelation to all of mankind.
 
 Some evangelical scholars interpret the law embodied in the Mosaic Covenant by emphasizing the distinctions between moral, civil, and ceremonial imperatives. But this approach is sometimes arbitrary and tends to ignore the narrative context. It also fails to fully reflect the significant implications of the change from the Old Covenant to the New Covenant of salvation inaugurated by Jesus Christ.
 
 An alternative approach seeks universal principles in the Old Testament moral laws and legal codes which can be adopted by Christian believers today. In other words, we should filter the universal principle through the New Testament teaching regarding that principle, or regarding the specific law being studied. This allows Christians to see that all scripture is "useful for teaching, rebuking, correcting, and training in righteousness". (2 Tim. 3:16)
 
 Old Testament Law can be understood as an ancient deposit of timeless ethical and theological principles, and the interpreter therefore must strive to discover the unchanging truth beneath its cultural carapace.

 If I may* ...
 
 Though it may seem subtle, I think you are conflating two very different things here. One of the things that changed with Christ is that of issues related to punishment. The passage you are referring to is about a punishment; it is not the sort of law that says "thou shalt not" do so-and-so. So no, this is not really an example of a "moral law" in the sense of moral-versus-ceremonial. It is an instruction about punishment (albeit very severe in this case). The admonition for a son to respect his father and mother IS still in place.
 
 To our 21st century eyes, in western culture, the idea of a son getting stoned for this seems incredibly harsh, but probably not so to the semitic culture a few thousand years ago. And so, this sort of thing has changed. However, the key point is that the law that demands children to obey their parents is indeed still in place, and it is the moral law here. It's just that we are to longer respond to the breaking of that law in the way prescribed in the passage you quote. THAT'S what has changed.

 Huck, you keep saying something came from nothing and then explain it with faith in a supernatural creature. This shows some flaws.
 
 One, you say that something came from nothing, so "god" caused the something. Evidently, something didn't come from nothing by this explanation. You're throwing "god" in place of the alleged gap. However, your explanation wipes out the foundation of the question it seeks to answer!
 
 Two, you ignore the law of conservation of mass-energy. It cannot be Created. Mass-energy was always here.
 
 Three, you have to presume that there was nothing. You have no reason to propose that there was nothing, and then demand an invalid explanation, but you still have the burden of proof to show that there was nothing. No one has evidence of nothing. It's analagous to asking, "What came from the pink unicorn?" No one has shown that there was a pink unicorn.
 
 Four, fact -- even perfect vacuums have energy. This may be mind boggling. Hopefully Hawking has a decent article about this. You can google vacuum fluctuations sometime.
 
 Five, the big bang doesn't say there was absolutely nothing before the big bang. The big bang is about what happened then and after.
 
 Six, you seek to explain your "faith" rationally. This makes no sense. Faith requires belief with no evidence. Ration requires logic, fact, and reasoning based on reality. Faith needs none of this.
 
 Seven, quantum theory shows how something can come from "nothing" although "nothing" isn't really nothing as we like to say it.
 
 Eighth, and this is touching the very limits of our common sense, not everything has to be "caused" or an "effect." I know, it just doesn't make sense. I still can't believe that radioactive decay is random.
 
 However, you can have all the faith you want. Don't try to use reasoning or science to get to it, since neither reasoning or science can exist without evidence, facts, or reality. Faith is belief, with no limit of being connected to reality. Religious people, superstitious people and schizophrenics can believe things with no proof, this is faith. 
 You are free to have faith just because. No need to try to attach reality to it.

As Ethan Allen put it: 
Those who invalidate reason ought seriously to consider whether they argue against reason with or without reason; if with reason, then they establish the principles that they are laboring to dethrone: but if they argue without reason (which, in order to be consistent with themselves they must do), they are out of reach of rational conviction, nor do they deserve a rational argument.
 Ethan Allen, "Reason, the Only Oracle of Man"

No problem of cosmology digs more deeply into the foundations of physics than the question of what preceded the initial state of infinite (or near infinite) density and temperature at the "moment" of the Big Bang.
 
 However, why is it "irrational" to approach the problem like this: 
 
 1. Everything that begins to exist has a cause of its existence.
 2. The universe began to exist.
 3. Therefore, the universe has a cause of its existence.
 
 And if we imagine the universe "jumping into existence" without a cause - which may not be logically impossible - it is inconsistent with everything we understand about the world in which we live. So why should we repudiate this intuition when we think about the origin of space and time?

 Perhaps the reader will wonder why we have placed our "beings" on a sphere rather than on another closed surface. But this choice has its justification in the fact that, of all closed surfaces, the sphere is unique in possessing the property that all points on it are equivalent. I admit that the ratio of the circumference c of a circle to its radius r depends on r, but for a given value of r it is the same for all points of the "world-sphere"; in other words, the "world-sphere" is a "surface of constant curvature." 6 
 To this two-dimensional sphere-universe there is a three-dimensional analogy, namely, the three-dimensional spherical space which was discovered by Riemann. Its points are likewise all equivalent. It possesses a finite volume, which is determined by its "radius" (22R3). Is it possible to imagine a spherical space? To imagine a space means nothing else than that we imagine an epitome of our "space" experience, i.e. of experience that we can have in the movement of "rigid" bodies.  a,b,c represent variable that further define the specific location of the center of the sphere in cartesian coordinate space.
